description:
Corynebacterium belfantii is a species of gram-positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile, rod-shaped bacterium. It is a member of the genus Corynebacterium, which are known to be part of the normal human skin and mucous membrane microbiota.

Corynebacterium belfantii was first isolated from the human respiratory tract and has been described as a slow-growing, aerobic bacterium. It is catalase-positive and can ferment various carbohydrates for energy production.

Phylogenetically, Corynebacterium belfantii is closely related to other Corynebacterium species, but it can be distinguished from them based on its unique biochemical and genetic characteristics. The species was named after the Belgian microbiologist Georges Belfanti, who contributed to the taxonomy and identification of Corynebacterium species.

While Corynebacterium belfantii is not considered a major human pathogen, it has been occasionally isolated from clinical samples and may be associated with opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand its potential role in human health and disease.
